tossups.question: In one type of system involving two of these objects, r theta double dot plus 2 r dot theta dot plus g sine theta equals 0. Systems involving multiple of these objects can be described as “rove to advantage” or “rove to disadvantage,” and the “Z-drag” is a specific system involving two of these devices. In Weston’s “differential” type of these devices, 2 over the quantity 1 minus little r over big R is the (*) mechanical advantage. In a system involving this device, acceleration equals m sub 1 minus m sub 2 all over m sub 1 plus m sub two, all multiplied by little g. The mechanical advantage of one of these devices is equal to the number of ropes supporting the load, and the block and tackle, and Atwood’s machine uses these devices. For 10 points, name these simple machines that consist of a wheel supporting movement of a taut rope.
tossups.answer: pulleys (anti-prompt on more specific answers such as “Atwood’s machine,” “block and tackle,” etc. before mention with “Can you be less specific?”) <Hao>
tossups.metadata: anti-prompt on more specific answers such as “Atwood’s machine,” “block and tackle,” etc. before mention with “Can you be less specific?”

tossups.question: A white villa, a large tree, and a pier leading to a steamship jetty appear in the background of this artist’s The Girls on the Bridge. He’s not Vincent van Gogh, but this man depicted his view from a beach resort in his 1892 painting Starry Night. In one of this man’s paintings, his younger sister Laura sits with her head bowed in the extreme foreground, mourning the death of his sister (*) Sophie; that painting is Death in the Sickroom which is part of his Frieze of Life series. This man’s most famous painting, whose sky may have been inspired by the eruption of Krakatoa, shows a grotesque figure performing the titular action. For 10 points, name this Norwegian painter of The Scream.

In one scene from this novel, a character explains that he had to place his bed in front of the back door in order to keep out a band of girls. Near the beginning of this novel the narrator tries to prevent two other characters from being whipped but later finds them still being flogged the next day. Earlier in this novel, the narrator fools around with a web-fingered servant of a (*) lawyer. That lawyer was hired for the protagonist by an uncle who is sometimes called Albert and sometimes Karl. Shortly after being told the parable “Before the Law,” the narrator dies “like a dog.” For ten points name this novel about Josef K., who is accused of an unknown crime by an inaccessible legal system, a work by Franz Kafka.

One of this thinker’s namesake fundamental equations gives the sum of earnings per unit output and the profit per unit output of the consumption goods sector. In one thought experiment, this thinker imagined a situation where it is rational to take public opinion into account when making a decision. Another concept outlined by this thinker is defined as the intersection of national output and aggregate demand. Those concepts are his namesake (*) “beauty contest” and his namesake “cross”, respectively . In one work, this thinker criticizes a peace treaty, and in another, he argued for countercyclical government spending. For ten points, name this British economist who wrote The Economic Consequences of the Peace and his General Theory first described “priming the pump” to stimulate an economy.

This country was home to a politician who sawed through a bar in a dormitory room to escape the Plymouth County Correctional Facility. That man ran for president on the crazy slogan “He killed my ma, he killed my pa, but I will vote for him,” having earlier split from Prince Johnson. In this country, William R. Tolbert Jr. was killed in a 1980 coup by Samuel (*) Doe. Another leader of this country was jointly awarded the 2011 Nobel Peace Prize with Tawakkol Karman and Leymah Gbowee. An October 2017 BBC article revealed that former warlord Charles Taylor may have influenced this country’s elections from his prison cell. For 10 points, name this African country recently led by Ellen Johnson Sirleaf that was settled by former American slaves.

In one work set in this country, a mother despairingly asks why her "darlin son" was "riddled with bullets." In another work set in this country, a murder that takes place after a horse race is denounced, even though the town had previously praised the murderer after he told a bar about having killed that same person with a blow to the head. In one play set in this country, Mrs. Madigan angrily takes away a gramophone after learning that the main family will not actually be inheriting a lot of money thanks to the incompetence of the lawyer Charles Bentham, who also got Mary pregnant. (*) In that work, Pegeen is heartbroken after it is revealed that Christy Mahon didn’t actually kill his father, and the two leave the Mayo coast. For 10 points, name this setting of The Playboy of the Western World and Juno and the Paycock, the home of John Millington Synge and Sean O'Casey.

During this period, Marina Mniszech, popularly known as “The Witch”, married two claimants to the throne in the country where it took place. This period included the reign of the only monarch from the Shuisky family. The father of the ruler whose reign ended this period was a church leader named Filaret. During this period, the eruption of the Peruvian volcano Huaynaputina in (*) 1600 caused a famine, killing one-third of a certain country’s population. This period included the Polish-Muscovite War and the rule of Boris Godunov, and it saw three pretenders known as “False Dimitris” claim the throne. This period was caused by the death of the Fyodor the Bellringer and lasted until Michael I took power in 1613. For 10 points, name this early 17th-century interregnum between the Rurikid and Romanov dynasties in Russia.

One technique used to image these compounds displays field strength on the x-axis and draws both absorbance and first-derivative curves; that technique commonly uses DMPO or PBN to increase the lifetime of its samples. Sawamoto, Wang, and Matyjaszewski independently discovered a living polymerization technique which uses these compounds, ATRP. These compounds can be analyzed by ESR spectroscopy, and the first of these compounds to be discovered (*), triphenylmethyl, was synthesized by Moses Gomberg. In reactions involving these compounds, fishhook arrows are used. The superoxide one of these compounds is generated in the mitochondria, and they’re neutralized in the body by Vitamins A, C, and E, which are antioxidants. For 10 points, name these very reactive molecules with unpaired electrons.

An artist from this country is best known for a series of oil fgs showing himself laughing. This country is home to an artist who created over three hundred artworks in New York City as part of his project Good Fences Make Good Neighbors. A red sun appears in the top right of one work from this country while a donkey pulls a cart on the left. One artist from this country filled the Tate Modern’s (*) Turbine Hall with millions of porcelain sunflower seeds. One artwork from this country shows onlookers shouting as a boat is about to crash into the Rainbow Bridge. The architectural firm Herzog & de Meuron designed the Bird’s Nest stadium in this country’s capital with help from Ai Weiwei. For 10 points, name this country where Zhang Zeduan created Along the River During the Qingming Festival.

One member of this school of thought stated that “nature hath given men one tongue but two ears that we may hear twice as much as we speak" and later stated that the goal of education should be to align one’s notion of rationality with nature’s. That thinker wrote the Enchiridion. Another member of this school stated that “the (*) wise man does not love wealth but still prefers it to poverty”. One member of this school proposed the dichotomy of providence or atoms in his most famous work and also instructed the reader to “erase impressions.” For ten points name this school of philosophy exemplified by Epictetus, Seneca the Younger, and Roman emperor, Marcus Aurelius.

The Risch algorithm is used to perform this operation in Mathematica, and Fatou’s lemma is an inequality relating limit inferiors and two types of this operation. Richardson extrapolation is used in Romberg’s method of performing this operation, and the discrete cosine transform is applied in the Clenshaw-Curtis quadrature for performing this operation. One multiplies by the Jacobian determinant to change (*) variables while performing this operation. Certain types of this operation require the norm of the normal vector and a parameterized function. One may change the order in which this operation is performed by Fubini’s theorem, and Stokes’s theorem relates the surface and line types of this operation. One method of approximating this operation uses quadratic equations and is named for Simpson. Often approximated by Riemann sums, for 10 points, name this operation that can find the area under a curve and is the counterpart of differentiation.

This person rejected the idea of worshipping the goddesses Manat, Uzza, and Lat. This person grew up as an orphan in an uncle’s house, Abu Talib, and married a successful merchant, Khadija. Khadija’s slave, Zaid, became this person’s companion and adopted son. This person’s other spouses include the favorite, Aisha. By riding a winged horse, al-Buraq, (*) this figure was able to undertake his Night Journey to heaven. In the Cave of Hira, Gabriel told this prophet to “recite.” After the Battle of Badr, this man fled from Mecca to Medina, called the hijrah. Sunnis forbid depictions of this man. For ten points, name this prophet who received the Quran and whose sayings are collected in hadiths, considered as the most important prophet in Islam.

Caves surrounding one of these objects are the only remaining habitat of the crucially endangered Gorgan salamander. An example of these features is located just above a permanent whirlpool known as the Boiling Pot. One of the four primary stops on the Diamond Circle is one of these objects that originates from the Vatnajokull glacier. An object of this type is the primary attraction of Guyana’s Kaieteur National Park. The most powerful of these objects in Europe is located in Iceland and is called (*) Dettifoss. The largest one of these objects is located near the summit of the Auyan-tepui mountain in Canaima National Park. Goat Island and Luna Island separate three adjacent groups of these features in the US and Canada. The tallest one of these features is located in Venezuela and named for Jimmy Angel. For 10 points, name these natural features, a group of which lie along the Niagara River.

In a story by this author, one character remarks that Americans are impressed by titles and that the narrator has “an extremely sensitive face.” The second section of that work centers on unnamed soldiers called X, Y, and Z. A character created by this author accuses a woman of looking at his feet in an elevator and tells her “don’t be a God-damned sneak about it.” The title creatures of the work in which that character appears (*) swim into holes and eat so much that they can’t get back through again and die. This creator of Seymour Glass also created a character who reminisces about playing checkers with his old friend Jane Gallagher and buys a record for his sister Phoebe. For 10 points, name this author of “For Esme - with Love and Squalor” and “A Perfect Day for Bananafish” who wrote about Holden Caulfield in The Catcher in the Rye.

Mouse models that may be used to study this disease include Q175 and R6/2 (“R 6 slash 2”). Austedo is a deuterated derivative of a drug used to treat this disease. Populations around Lake Maracaibo have an abnormally high rate of this disease. This disease shows caudate and putamen atrophy on MRI, and the mutated protein in this disease is SUMOylated by Rhes. The first FDA-approved treatment for this disease is believed to act through VMAT2 inhibition and is called (*) tetrabenazine. This disease occurs with increasing frequency in successive generations in a process known as anticipation. This disease is classified as “full penetrance” if there are more than 40 CAG repeats, which cause excess glutamine in a polyQ region of the protein Htt. For 10 points, name this autosomal dominant genetic disease that causes its namesake jerky movements, called chorea.

This dynasty took power after its leader killed his main rival in the town of Abusir. For almost 100 years, this dynasty’s capital was ruled by the neighboring Buyid dynasty. During this dynasty, the first recorded paper mill was introduced by the noble Barmakid family. This dynasty ended when its last ruler, Al Mutawakkil III, was deposed in Cairo by Selim I. It arose from a revolt by a general who flew the (*) Black Standard flag, and it defeated its predecessor at the Battle of the Zab. In 1258, its caliph Al-Mu’tasim was rolled in a carpet and stamped to death after Hulagu Khan sacked its capital at Baghdad. For 10 points, name this third Islamic caliphate which took over control of the Muslim empire from the Umayyads.

This man repurposed the second movement of a planned oboe concerto into his final work, a Canzonetta for oboe and string orchestra. His piano concerto includes a ridiculously fast B-flat minor third movement in 5/8 time, as well as a Canzone second movement. Over a period of 40 years, this composer completed a series of one-movement orchestral works known as “essays”. One of this man’s works was written for (*) Iso Briselli, who refused to play it because its moto perpetuo third movement was too difficult. This man set a James Agee text for soprano and orchestra in his Knoxville: Summer of 1915. This man’s best known work was arranged from the second movement of his only string quartet and was played at FDR’s funeral. For 10 points, name this American composer of Adagio for Strings.

Some legal scholars have claimed the decision in this case was effectively reversed by Berghuis v. Thompkins. In a partial concurrence and partial dissent, Justice Tom C. Clark argued that the majority in this case went “too far too fast” in its ruling. The outcome of this case was determined to be a constitutional rule in (*) Dickerson v. U.S, and it expanded on a decision reached two years earlier in Escobedo v. Illinois. Full dissents in this case were given by John Marshall Harlan II and Byron White. The defendant in this case was not told that he could have an attorney or remain silent after being arrested for kidnapping and rape near Phoenix. For 10 points, name this 1966 Supreme Court case which established that suspects had to be read certain rights.

The Lithuanian deity of this type is often portrayed with a utensil in his right hand and a rooster on his head. In Inuit mythology, Sedna becomes a goddess of this when she attacks her parents out of great hunger. Another deity of this type harbors a grudge against Tāne because Tāne sheltered his children in the forests. The Celtic deity of this, Lir, had his children turned into swans by Aoife (pronounced EE-fuh). In Chinese mythology, the deity of this was Mazu, who often patrolled her domain performing miracles for her followers. Prior to his death, Osiris was the god of this, and (*) Sobek now governs this in Egyptian mythology. Another deity of this type helped Apollo build the walls of Troy and lost a contest to Athena due to his inferior gift to the city of Athens. For 10 points, name this domain, governed by individuals such as Varuna, Oceanus, and Poseidon.
tossups.answer: Sea or God of the Sea or similar phrases (Do not accept or prompt on “Ocean”) <Orlov>
tossups.answer_formatted: Sea or God of the Sea or similar phrases <Orlov>
acceptable: Sea or God of the Sea or similar phrases <Orlov>
Sea or God of the Sea or similar phrases <Orlov>
tossups.metadata: Do not accept or prompt on “Ocean”

tossups.question: During one scene in this work, a character is served a wine called “Upon Leaving the Door You will Fall Down.” At the beginning of this work, Marshal Hong orders the removal of a stone tortoise. A hairy priest who kills a tiger with his bare hands in this work is the basis for a sexually explicit work titled The (*) Plum in the Golden Vase. Many characters in the work die while fighting Fang La’s rebel forces in the south. In this work, Song Jian leads a group of reincarnated demons called the “heavenly stars of destiny” against the corrupt official Gao Qiu. For 10 points, name this Shi Nai’an work, a classic Chinese novel about a group of 108 bandits.
tossups.answer: Water Margin (accept Outlaws of the Marsh) <Kodama> BONUSES

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about actors named Chris. For 10 points each:
answers: Hitting Captain America’s shield with Thor’s hammer (Description acceptable)
parts: Name this actor, who gained fame for portraying Starlord in the Guardians of the Galaxy films and also played Andy Dwyer in the NBC comedy-drama Parks and Recreation and Owen Grady in Jurassic World.
Two more famous actors named Chris have an iconic scene together in a Marvel film when their immense strength causes them blow down an entire forest using the shockwave produced from doing this.
This other famous Chris directed three wildly successful films that starred Christian Bale, along with The Prestige and Interstellar.
answers_formatted: Hitting Captain America’s shield with Thor’s hammer
acceptable: Hitting Captain America’s shield with Thor’s hammer
Hitting Captain America’s shield with Thor’s hammer

bonuses.leadin: This poet described a woman “of cloudless climes and starry skies” in “She Walks in Beauty”. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this British poet of Manfred and Childe Harold’s Pilgrimage.

In this Lord Byron poem, Selim, who is raised by the pasha Giaffir, falls in love with his supposed half-sister Zuleika. Selim is later killed by Giaffir and Zuleika commits suicide at the end of this work.
In this Lord Byron poem, the easily seduced title character becomes favored by Catherine the Great after escaping a harem in Constantinople.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about double concertos. For 10 points each:
parts: One of the most famous double concertos is a D minor work for two violins by this composer of the Goldberg Variations.
This man composed an E minor concerto for two pianos during his Neoclassical period. He also wrote a “Concerto for Piano and Winds" and the Symphony of Psalms.

Another double concerto is this German’s Concerto for Clarinet, Viola, and Orchestra. This composer of three violin concertos set the Kol Nidrei for cello and orchestra and is also known for his Scottish Fantasy.

bonuses.leadin: This historical figure defeated the Elamite king Teumman and crushed the Kingdom of Kush. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this son of Esarhaddon, better known for his large library of cuneiform tablets.
Ashurbanipal ruled this empire, which he governed from Nineveh. This empire founded by Adad-nirari II was also ruled by Sennacherib.
This other Assyrian king conquered Syria and Palestine, as well as taking over the Babylonian throne in 728 BCE. He also established the first professional Assyrian standing army.

bonuses.leadin: The three structural genes in this structure are usually named Z, Y, and A. This structure also contains a promoter and a terminator. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this structure which is responsible for the metabolism and transport of its namesake sugar. It was first observed in E.coli.

E.coli is an example of these types of organisms, which are used to study the biology of a wider range of organisms. Other types of these organisms include Drosophila melanogaster and Saccharomyces cerevisiae.

Another operon discovered in E.coli encodes for the production of this amino acid. This aromatic amino acid, which is encoded by the codon UGG, is the starting reactant for the biosynthesis of melatonin.

bonuses.leadin: At the beginning of this novel, one character leaves Saint Petersburg to become aide-de-camp to Mikhail Kutuzov. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this extremely long Leo Tolstoy novel centered on Prince Andrey Bolkonsky and Natasha Rostova.
In War and Peace, this dissolute son of Vassily Kuragin marries a Polish woman before abandoning her. He tries to elope with Natasha, resulting in the breaking of her engagement with Prince Andrey.
This character is inspired by gematria to assassinate Napoleon and later meets the peasant Platon Karataev. He marries Natasha at the end of the novel.

bonuses.leadin: Name some things about everyone’s favorite field of philosophical study: phenomenology. For 10 points each:
parts: This philosopher is generally held to be the founder of phenomenology. He is also known for writing Logical Investigations and Cartesian Meditations and for developing the idea of “lifeworld.”
This Christian phenomenologist and subject of Pope John Paul II’s thesis, rejected Husserl’s idea of bracketing and argued that intuition of consciousness requires the suspension of impulse.
This author of The Problems of Phenomenology is perhaps better known for his alignment with the Nazi party. He also developed the idea of Dasein and wrote Being and Time.

bonuses.leadin: Following this event, Lachlan Macquarie was appointed governor of a certain colony. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this rebellion, caused by James MacArthur’s importation of the titular alcoholic drink.
This man’s misfortunes continued when he was deposed in the Rum Rebellion. Fifteen years earlier, Fletcher Christian had mutinied against him on the Bounty.
The Rum Rebellion occurred in this country, which was founded by resettled convicts in what is now Sydney.

bonuses.leadin: A Dean-Stark trap might be used to separate these substances. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these substances which can be classified as either positive or negative. They are deviations from Raoult's Law.
Ethanol famously forms an azeotrope when its volume is this percentage of the total volume of a solution with water. Answers will be accepted to within 3 percent on both sides.
N-butanol and water form one of these types of azeotropes at 93.5 degrees Celsius. These types of azeotropes have a vapor phase coexisting with two liquid phases.

bonuses.leadin: Several architects worked extensively in Brazil. For 10 points each:
parts: Brazil’s largest city, Sao Paulo, was planned by this Swiss-born architect whose other South American designs include the Curutchet House. He is better known for houses like the Villa Savoye and the book Toward an Architecture.

Sao Paulo’s Edificio Copan residential complex was designed by this man, who incorporated several blue shells into his Church of Saint Francis of Assisi. His best-known city plan features buildings like the Palace of Dawn and a hyperboloid-shaped cathedral.

This other Brazilian architect designed Rio’s Gustavo Capanema Palace with Niemeyer and Roberto Burle Marx. While Niemeyer designed Brasilia’s civic buildings, this man developed a “pilot plan” to lay out the city.

bonuses.leadin: Many people have claimed to be the Second Coming of Jesus Christ. For 10 points each,
answers: Shakers or the United Society of Believers in Christ’s Second Coming
Reverend Sun Myung Moon [accept Reverend Moon Sun Myung] <Mathew>
parts: “Mother” Ann was the founder of this American Protestant sect, and followers believed she was a counterpart to Jesus. This religion’s surviving members live in Sabbathday Lake, Maine.
This other American, who took the name of “the Prophet,” led a mass suicide in Guyana through drinking Kool-Aid with cyanide.
This man who claims to be the Messiah and his wife are considered the “True Parents” of the Unification Church.
answers_formatted: Shakers or the United Society of Believers in Christ’s Second Coming
Reverend Sun Myung Moon <Mathew> [accept Reverend Moon Sun Myung]
acceptable: Shakers or the United Society of Believers in Christ’s Second Coming
Shakers or the United Society of Believers in Christ’s Second Coming

bonuses.leadin: This man described Nelida’s longing for the dead Juan Carlos Etchepare in Heartbreak Tango. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Argentine author, who wrote about the impact of films on Toto Casals in Betrayed by Rita Hayworth.
This other film-related Puig novel describes the relationship between the gay cellmates Valentin and Molina.
This more famous Argentine author wrote the short stories “Pierre Menard, Author of the Quixote” as well as “The Garden of Forking Paths.”

bonuses.leadin: This painter of several Metaphysical Interiors often included trains and bunches of bananas in his work. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Italian painter who showed a Greek sculpture and surgeon’s glove attached to a wall in his work Love Song.

A girl rolls a hoop towards a shadowy figure in a de Chirico painting about the “Mystery and Melancholy” of one of these things. Gustave Caillebotte painted another of these things in Paris on a rainy day.
A 1950 work by de Chirico depicts this city and its Puente de Rialto. The Stonemason’s Yard is one of several paintings set in this city by Canaletto.

bonuses.leadin: This event led to the resignations of Elliot Richardson and William Ruckelshaus. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this event in which Richard Nixon fired special prosecutor Archibald Cox.
The Saturday Night Massacre was part of this political scandal, which was investigated by journalists Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein.
Deep Throat, an informant for Woodward and Bernstein, was revealed in 2005 to be this then-associate director of the FBI.

bonuses.leadin: A discovery of this mineral on Mars is often presented as proof that water once flowed on the planet. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this mineral, whose variants include selenite and alabaster.
This is the only mineral lower than gypsum on the Mohs hardness scale. It is often used in baby powder and is composed of hydrated magnesium silicate.
Talc comprises most of this metamorphic rock, which is also known as steatite. This acid-resistant rock is often used in countertops and floor tiles.

bonuses.leadin: While many famous bridges go to heaven, some lead elsewhere. For 10 points each:
parts: This burning rainbow bridge connects Asgard and Midgard. Watched over by Heimdallr, it will be broken when the gods march over it at Ragnarök.
This other Norse bridge spans the river Gjöll and must be crossed to reach Hel. It is typically described as covered and thatched with glittering gold and is protected by the giantess Módgud.
Gjallarbrú was famously crossed by Hermód after he was sent to retrieve this figure from the land of the dead after he was killed by a dart made of mistletoe, his only weakness.

bonuses.leadin: This physicist apocryphally stated that “it is not even wrong!” when confronted with an unfalsifiable theory. An “effect” named after this man referred to the likelihood of lab equipment breaking while he was in the vicinity. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this physicist who also names a procedure used to isolate divergent terms from loop integrals with Villars. He also names 2 by 2 matrices that can be used to describe the spin of a particle.
Pauli theorized the existence of these particles, which are fermions that interact only via the weak force and gravity.
In 1940, Pauli re-derived this theorem, which states that the wavefunction of a system stays the same if two identical bosons are swapped, but it changes sign if two identical fermions are swapped.

bonuses.leadin: Several events shaped Ireland’s struggle for independence. For 10 points each:
parts: The British army suppressed this 1916 armed uprising, named for the holiday during which it occurred. This uprising, started by Patrick Pearse and James Connolly, was organized by the Irish Republican Brotherhood
The Easter Rising mostly took place in this city. This capital of Ireland was also the site of the Phoenix Park Murders.
This period of unrest in late 19th century Ireland began after a namesake conference passed a resolution demanding the so-called “three Fs”. It was ended by a 1903 act named for George Wyndham.

bonuses.leadin: This event resulted from the invoking of Article 50 in March 2017. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this event, the withdrawal of the UK from the European Union.

This current British Foreign Secretary was a prominent leader of the Brexit campaign. He infamously claimed the Libyan city of Sirte could become a new Dubai if “[they] cleared all the dead bodies away”.

This group led by Arlene Foster was the only political party in Northern Ireland to back “Leave” during the Brexit campaign. After the June 2017 special elections, Theresa May’s conservatives stayed in power by forming a coalition with this party.

bonuses.leadin: This man described “The Awful German Language” in the appendix of his A Tramp Abroad. For 10 points each:
answers: The Gilded Age: A Tale of Today
parts: Name this American author more famous for The Adventures of Tom Sawyer.
Twain collaborated with Charles Dudley Warner on this book centered on the Hawkins family. Its title now refers to the economic boom after the Civil War.
Twain was also noted for his travel writings, including this book detailing his “Great Pleasure Excursion” through Europe on the vessel Quaker City.
answers_formatted: The Gilded Age: A Tale of Today
acceptable: The Gilded Age: A Tale of Today
Gilded Age: A Tale of Today
